May 31, 1981: Fiction
NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese
businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses.
GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in
Moscow leads to a chase across two continents.
FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.)
Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon.
GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues
as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet
Dune.
THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen
thousand years of South African history.
CREATION, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $15.95.) A journey through that
greatest of all ages, the fifth century B.C., in the company of a man critical of it all.
TAR BABY, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $11.95.) A black fable of race and eroticism
set on a Caribbean island.
REFLEX, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A British jockey copes with
blackmail and discovers his own missing past.
MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) An illustrated fable
about the Sun, the Moon and a hidden treasure.
THE WHITE HOTEL, by D.M. Thomas. (Viking, $12.95.) Sigmund Freud treats a
young woman whose case epitomizes the neuroses of the 20th century.
XPD, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $12.95.) The British and the Russians race to get
proof that Churchill once did business with Hitler.
CENTURY, by Fred Mustard Stewart. (Morrow, $13.95.) Saga of an Italian-
American family.
THE COMPANY OF WOMEN, by Mary Gordon. (Random House, $12.95.) One
modern young woman's experience with the manners and mores of Roman
Catholicism.
LICENSE RENEWED, by John Gardner. (Richard Marek, $9.95.) James Bond
against a mad nuclear physicist.
THE MIDWIFE, by Gay Courter. (Houghton Mifflin, $12.95.) A Jewish midwife
practices her art in Russia and America at the turn of the century.
Non-Fiction
THE LORD GOD MADE THEM ALL, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) The
further adventures of the Yorkshire vet at home and behind the Iron Curtain.
NEVER-SAY-DIET BOOK, by Richard Simmons. (Warner, $14.95.) Regimen for
exercise, diet and life style.
COSMOS, by Carl Sagan. (Random House, $19.95.) Thirteen billion years of the
universe's evolution explained by the NASA medal-winning space scientist.
THE BEVERLY HILLS DIET, by Judy Mazel. (Macmillan, $9.59.) A regimen
devised by a Hollywood nutrition guru.
PAVAROTTI: My Own Story, by Luciano Pavarotti with William Wright.
(Doubleday, $14.95.) The leading tenor, "King of the High C's," talks about his life
and his art.
DR. ATKINS' NUTRITION BREAKTHROUGH, by Robert C. Atkins, M.D.
(Perigord/Morrow, $10.95.) How common illnesses can be treated without drugs,
but with diets supplemented by vitamins and minerals.
WILLIAM E. DONOGHUE'S COMPLETE MONEY MARKET GUIDE, by William E.
Donoghue with Thomas Tilling. (Harper & Row, $12.95.) "How to profit from
inflation and fluctuating interest rates."
MARIA CALLAS, by Arianna Stassinopoulos. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) A
gossipy biography of an extraordinary singer and electrifying personality.
THE EAGLE'S GIFT, by Carlos Castaneda. (Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) Another
journey into the land of sorcery, hallucinatory visions and Mexican Indian lore.
BETTY CROCKER'S INTERNATIONAL COOKBOOK. (Random House, $13.95.)
A new collection of recipes under a long-established name.
NICE GIRLS DO, by Irene Kassorla. (Stratford Press, $9.95.) "How women may
solve their own sexual problems."
YOU CAN NEGOTIATE ANYTHING, by Herb Cohen. (Lyle Stuart, $12.) Ways to
avoid conflict and get what you want.
WEALTH AND POVERTY, by George Gilder. (Basic Books, $16.95.) The case for
capitalism and for a reduction in the tax rate.
PAPER MONEY, by Adam Smith. (Summit, $13.95.) An economist throws light on
that mysterious thing, money.
CRAIG CLAIBORNE'S GOURMET DIET, by Craig Clairborne with Pierre Franey.
(Times Books, $10.95.) Recipes for eating well, losing weight and maintaining
